name: host_systemd_service_crashed_instance_incident
description: This incident type refers to the failure of a systemd service on a particular host instance. The incident could be triggered by various causes such as a software bug, hardware failure, or system overload. This type of incident can cause downtime or service disruption to the affected host instance, which may require immediate resolution to restore normal operations.

cells.name: cell_1
cells.content:
## Host systemd service crashed (instance) incident.
This incident type refers to the failure of a systemd service on a particular host instance. The incident could be triggered by various causes such as a software bug, hardware failure, or system overload. This type of incident can cause downtime or service disruption to the affected host instance, which may require immediate resolution to restore normal operations.

cells.name: cell_2
cells.content: ## Check the status of the systemd service on the affected host instance

cells.name: cell_3
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `systemctl status ${SERVICE_NAME}`

cells.name: cell_4
cells.content: ## Check the systemd journal for logs related to the service crash

cells.name: cell_5
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `journalctl -u ${SERVICE_NAME} -b`

cells.name: cell_6
cells.content: ## Check the system logs for any relevant error messages

cells.name: cell_7
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `dmesg | grep ${SERVICE_NAME}`

cells.name: cell_8
cells.content: ## Check the CPU and memory usage on the affected host instance

cells.name: cell_9
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `top`

cells.name: cell_10
cells.content: ## Check the disk usage and available space on the affected host instance

cells.name: cell_11
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `df -h`

cells.name: cell_12
cells.content: ## Check the network connectivity on the affected host instance

cells.name: cell_13
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `ping ${IP_ADDRESS}`

cells.name: cell_14
cells.content: ## Check the firewall rules on the affected host instance

cells.name: cell_15
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `iptables -L`

cells.name: cell_16
cells.content: ## Check the hardware status of the affected host instance

cells.name: cell_17
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `sensors`

cells.name: cell_18
cells.content: ## The host system's resources were overloaded due to high usage or traffic, causing the systemd service to fail.

cells.name: cell_19
cells.content: host | host_name=$HOST_NAME | invoke_cpu_mem_restart_service($SYSTEMD_SERVICE_NAME)

cells.name: cell_20
cells.content: ## Restart the systemd service on the affected host instance: This can be done to try and resolve the issue by manually restarting the systemd service on the affected host instance. If the failure was due to a temporary issue, the service should resume normal operations after restarting.

cells.name: cell_21
cells.content: host | host_name=$HOST_NAME | invoke_restart_systemd_service($SYSTEMD_SERVICE_NAME, $HOST_INSTANCE)
